## QCD Topology {auto-animate=true auto-animate-easing="ease-in-ease-out"}
Full QCD Euclidean action:

::: {class="fragment"}
$$S_{\text{QCD}} =
\int d^4x~ 
\frac{1}{2g^2} \mathrm{Tr} \left[G_{\mu\nu}(x) G_{\mu\nu}(x)\right]
+ \int d^4x~\sum_f \bar{\psi}_f(x) (\gamma_\mu D_\mu + m_f)\psi_f(x)
\;+\;
 \theta Q $$
:::

## QCD Topology {auto-animate=true auto-animate-easing="ease-in-ease-out"}
Full QCD Euclidean action:

::: {.class}
$$S_{\text{QCD}} =
\int d^4x~ 
\frac{1}{2g^2} \mathrm{Tr} \left[G_{\mu\nu}(x) G_{\mu\nu}(x)\right]
+ \int d^4x~\sum_f \bar{\psi}_f(x) (\gamma_\mu D_\mu + m_f)\psi_f(x)
\;+\;
 \textcolor{#EB811B}{\theta Q} $$
:::

::: {class="fragment"}
The θ-term couples to the **topological charge**:

::: {.class style="text-align:center;"}
$$
Q = \frac{1}{32\pi^2} \int d^4x~ 
\varepsilon_{\mu\nu\rho\sigma} \,
\text{Tr}[G_{\mu\nu} G_{\rho\sigma}]
$$
:::
:::

::: {class="fragment"}
- In the continuum: $ Q $ in $\mathbb{Z}$  
- Each integer labels a distinct **topological sector**
:::

1. At $T \gg T_c$ (${\sim}155$ MeV)→ **Deconfinement**
 <!--quarks and gluons are the relevant degrees of freedom (Asymptotic Freedom).-->

:::

::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top: 0px;margin-left:-50px;font-size: 0.85em;"}
2. QCD interactions are vector-like<br> 
<span style="font-size:0.9em; color:#888">preserve CP globally at $\small \theta=0$</span>

$$\underbrace{\langle N_L-N_R }_{\color{#EB811B}\large N_5}\rangle=0$$

<!--at equilibrium -->
:::

::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top: 0px; margin-left:-50px; font-size: 0.85em;"}
3. **But** topology can induce local imbalance: <br>
  <span style="font-size:0.9em; color:#888">via Atiyah-Singer Index Theorem</span>

  $$ Q = \int d^4x \, q(x) = N_L - N_R \equiv N_5$$
  <div style="margin-top:10px; font-size:0.9em; color:#af1212ff">
  $~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~\Rightarrow$ Fluctuations of $Q$ drive $N_5 \neq 0$
  </div>
:::

::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top: -40px ;margin-left:-50px; font-size: 0.85em;text-align:center;"}
<strong>Finite Sphaleron Rate</strong> ($\Gamma_{\text{sphal}} \neq 0$)

:::

::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top: -10px;margin-left:-50px;font-size: 0.85em; text-align:center;"}
↓
:::

::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top: -10px;margin-left:-50px;font-size: 0.85em; text-align:center;"}
<strong>Barrier Crossing:</strong> <br>
      Thermal fluctuations overcome the energy barrier separating distinct topological vacua.
:::

::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top: 30px; margin-left:-50px; font-size: 0.85em;"}
<strong>The Anomaly:</strong> <br>
      Transitions change  $Q$, driving axial charge via:
      $$ \partial_\mu j^\mu_5 = 2N_f \underbrace{\frac{g^2}{32\pi^2} G_{\mu\nu}\tilde{G}^{\mu\nu}}_{q(x)} $$
<!-- \Delta N_5 = 2N_f\, \Delta Q_{\text{top}}.-->
:::

::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top: -20px; margin-left:-50px; font-size: 0.85em;"}
<strong>Result:</strong> <br>
      Creation of local <strong>Chiral Imbalance</strong>:
      
$$\Delta Q \neq 0 \Rightarrow \Delta N_5 \neq 0 \Rightarrow \mathrm{e.g.}~~ N_L > N_R $$

## 2) Axion Cosmology & Sphalerons

::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="1" style="margin-bottom: 30px; border-left: 5px solid #EB811B; padding-left: 15px; background: rgba(235, 129, 27, 0.05);"}
**The Axion:** <br>A pseudo-Goldstone boson proposed to solve the **Strong CP Problem**
 and also a leading **Dark Matter** candidate.
:::

::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="2"}
**Thermal Production:**<br>
Early Universe ($\small T \sim T_c \div 10 T_c$) → axions  produced via hadronic scatterings:
$$\small \pi + \pi \to a + a $$
:::

::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="3" style="margin-top: 5px; font-size: 0.9em;"}
The axion relic abundance is governed by the **Boltzmann Equation** [cite: 81-82]:
$$ \small \frac{df_{\vec{p}}}{dt} = (1+f_{\vec{p}})\Gamma_{a}^{(+)} - f_{\vec{p}}\Gamma_{a}^{(-)} $$
:::

::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="4" style="margin-bottom: 10px; border-left: 5px solid rgba(4, 41, 110, 0.84); padding-left: 15px; background: rgba(13, 61, 150, 0.04);"}
**The Key Input:**
The interaction rates $\Gamma_a$ are realted to the **Sphaleron Rate**[cite: 84]:

<div style="font-size: 1.1em; text-align:center; color: #0c2344; font-weight:bold; margin-top:-20px;">
$$ \small \Gamma_a^{(-)}=e^{E/T}\; \Gamma_a^{(+)}=\frac{\Gamma_{\text{sphal}}}{2 E f_a^2} $$
</div>
:::

<!--
$\Rightarrow$ A precise lattice determination of **$\Gamma_{\text{sphal}}$** is essential to constrain the **Cosmic Axion Background**.
-->

## From Real Time to Euclidean Time 
<div style="margin-bottom: 20px;">
  The Sphaleron Rate is a <span style="color: #EB811B; font-weight:bold;">Real-Time</span> Transport Coefficient:
  $$ \Gamma_{\text{sphal}} = \int dt\, d^3x~ \langle q(\vec{x}, t)\, q(\vec{0}, 0)\rangle_T $$
</div>

::: {class="fragment fade-in" data-fragment-index="2" style="margin-top: 30px;"}
But lattice simulations live in **Euclidean time** ($t \to -i\tau$):
$$ 0 \le \tau \le 1/T $$
:::

::: {class="fragment fade-in" data-fragment-index="3"}
We measure the **Euclidean Correlator** (spatially integrated):
$$ G_E(\tau) = \int d^3x \, \langle q(\vec{x}, \tau)\, q(\vec{0}, 0)\rangle $$
:::

::: {class="fragment fade-in" data-fragment-index="4" style="margin-top: 30px; margin-left:320px; color: gray; font-style: italic; text-align: center;"}
[**The Challenge:**]{style="color: #EB811B ;"}<br> How to recover dynamic transport $\Gamma_{\mathrm{sphal}}$ from lattice data $G_E(\tau)$?
:::


## Spectral Representation {auto-animate=true}

Spectral Decomposition of Euclidean Correlators

$$
G(\tau)
= -\int_0^\infty \frac{d\omega}{\pi}~ K(\tau,\omega)\,\rho(\omega)
$$

## Spectral Representation {auto-animate=true}

Spectral Decomposition of Euclidean Correlators

$$
G(\tau)
=- \int_0^\infty \frac{d\omega}{\pi}~ { K(\tau,\omega)}\,{\color{#EB811B}\rho(\omega)}
$$

with the thermal Laplace basis

$$\small K(\tau,\omega)= \frac{\cosh\!\left(\omega(\tau-\tfrac{1}{2T})\right)} {\sinh\!\left(\tfrac{\omega}{2T}\right)} $$

:::columns
:::column
::: {class="fragment"}
The **spectral function** encodes:

* excitations at finite $\omega$  
* **transport** from its behaviour at $\small \omega \to 0$
:::
:::
:::column
::: {class="fragment"  style="margin-bottom: 0px; border-left: 5px solid #EB811B; padding-left: 15px; background: rgba(235, 129, 27, 0.05);"}
* **For the Sphaleron Rate:** []
<div style="font-size: 1.1em; text-align:center;margin-left:100px;font-weight:bold; margin-top:-10px;">
$$\small \Gamma_{\text{sphal}}=\lim_{\omega\to 0}\frac{2T}{\omega}\,\rho(\omega)$$
</div>
:::
:::

## The Inverse Problem: A Mathematical Wall 

## The Inverse Problem: A Mathematical Wall {auto-animate=true}

<div style="margin-top: 20px; border: 2px solid #666; padding: 0px; border-radius: 15px;">
  $$ G_E({\color{ #EB811B}\tau_i}) =- \int_0^\infty \frac{d\omega}{\pi} \, K({\color{ #EB811B}\tau_i}, \omega) \, \rho(\omega) $$
</div>

::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}


<div style="margin-top: 30px; font-size: 0.9em;">
**Input from the Lattice:**

* Finite set of points: $N_\tau \sim \mathcal{O}(10-20)$
* Noisy data: $G_E(\tau_i) \pm \sigma_i$
</div>
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
<div class="fragment" style="margin-top: 30px; font-size: 0.9em;">
**The Unknown (Physics):**

* Continuous function $\rho(\omega) = \mathcal{L}^{-1}\{G_E\}(\omega)$
* Infinite degrees of freedom
</div>

:::
:::

<div class="fragment" style="margin-top: 40px; border-left: 5px solid #EB811B; padding-left: 20px; padding-top: 5px; padding-bottom: 10px; background: #ec811d1f;">
  <strong style="color:#EB811B">The Problem:</strong><br>
  This is a **Fredholm Integral Equation of the 1st Kind** ⇒ **Ill-Posed**.<br>
   An infinite number of solutions $\rho(\omega)$ can fit the discrete data within error bars.
</div>

## Discretization & Mock Tests
<div style="text-align:center; margin-top:-20px;">
Synthetic Data ⇒ $G(\tau _i) = \sum _j K(\tau _i, \omega _j) \rho (\omega _j)$
</div>
<img class="fragment" src="mock2/catastrophe_forward.svg" width="100%" style="margin-top:-40px;">
<img class="fragment" src="mock2/illposed_kernel_svd.svg" width="100%" style="margin-top:-40px;">

## Direct Inversion: a Catastrophe!
<div style="text-align:center; margin-top:-10px;">
**Naive inversion:**  &nbsp;  ${\rho} \sim K^{-1}\, G$
</div>

<img src="mock2/catastrophe_inverse.svg" style="width:100%; margin-top:-40px;"/>





<!--
<div style="font-size: 0.8em; margin-top: 0px;">

  * **Singular values $\sigma_i$ collapse**  → the effective rank of $K$ is tiny.
  * **Noise amplification:**  small $\sigma_i$ imply $1/\sigma_i$ grows huge  
    → even $1\%$ noise in $G_E$ becomes $\mathcal{O}(100\%)$ in $\rho$.
  * **Pathologies:**  large oscillations, overshoots, negative spikes — pure numerical artefacts.
  * **Non-uniqueness:**  many different $\rho(\omega)$ reproduce the same $G_E(\tau)$ within errors.

  <br>

  *Pointwise reconstruction of $\rho(\omega)$ is mathematically unstable → the inverse problem is ill-posed.*
</div>
-->
<div class="fragment" style="margin-top: 15px; border-top: 2px solid #EB811B; padding-top: 10px; text-align: center;">
  To overcome ill-posedness, we must abandon pointwise reconstruction.<br>
We instead target a <strong>smeared spectral density</strong> using a <strong>regularized estimator</strong> that suppresses noise amplification.
</div>

## Breaking the Wall: 1.Smearing

<div style="margin-bottom: 20px;">
  Sharp features $\rho(\omega)$ cannot be reconstructed →
  <span style="color: #EB811B; font-weight:bold;">Smeared Spectral Density</span>:
</div>

$$
\frac{\bar{\rho}_\sigma(\bar{\omega})}{\bar \omega}
= 
\int_0^\infty d\omega \,
\Delta_\sigma(\bar{\omega}, \omega) \,
\frac{\rho(\omega)}{\omega}
$$

::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top: 30px;"}
Here $\Delta_\sigma$ is a **target smearing kernel** which replaces the ideal $\delta(\omega-\bar\omega)$ that we cannot resolve.
:::

::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top: 30px; border-left: 5px solid #EB811B; padding-left: 15px;"}
**The HLT Strategy:**  
Rather than solving directly for $\rho(\omega)$, we determine coefficients $g_\tau(\bar\omega)$ such that
<!--
We approximate the smeared rate $\bar{\rho}$ as a linear combination of the measured Euclidean correlators
and linearity of the integral implies
-->
$$
\Delta_\sigma(\bar{\omega},\omega) 
\approx 
\sum_{\tau=t_{\mathrm{min}}}^{N_\tau/2} g_\tau(\bar{\omega}) \, K(\tau, \omega).
$$

Then the smeared estimator becomes:

$$
\boxed{
\;\bar{\rho}_\sigma(\bar{\omega})
\;\approx\;
\sum_{\tau=t_{\mathrm{min}}}^{N_\tau/2} g_\tau(\bar{\omega})\, G_E(\tau)
}
$$
:::


## Smearing Mock Test

<div class="fragment" data-fragment-index="2" style="font-size: 0.85em; margin-top: 10px; border-left: 4px solid #EB811B; padding-left: 15px; background: rgba(235, 129, 27, 0.05); margin-top:-20px;">

<!--
**Unregularized Reconstruction:**
$\Delta$ tries to perfectly mimic $\delta(\omega)$ $\Rightarrow$ leads to wild oscillations, negative regions, and explosive coefficients $|g|$.
-->
**The Trade-off:**

* **Narrower target $\sigma$** $\Rightarrow$ sharper $\Delta$ but $\|g\| \uparrow$ explodes.
* **Broader $\sigma$** $\Rightarrow$ stable $\Delta$, reduced variance, but poorer resolution.
* **Goal:** Need optimal $\sigma$ + damping ($\lambda$ reg.) to balance width vs. noise.



</div>
<div style="margin-top:-30px;">
<img class="fragment" data-fragment-index="1" src="mock3/Delta_g_unreg_combo.svg" style="width:100%; "/>
</div>

<div class="fragment" style="margin-top: 15px; border-top: 2px solid #EB811B; padding-top: 10px; text-align: center;">
  We now introduce regularization [(**Modified Backus–Gilbert / HLT**)]{style="color: #EB811B;"} to set $\sigma$ and suppress unstable modes.
</div>


## the HLT functional
<div style="text-align:center;margin-top:-20px; margin-bottom: 0px; font-size: 1.1em;">
  We determine the coefficients $g_\tau(\bar\omega)$ by minimizing the functional:
  
  $$W_\lambda[g] = (1-\lambda) A[g] + \lambda B[g]$$
</div>

::: columns
::: column 
:::{class="fragment"}
<div style="border: 1px solid #444; padding: 15px; border-radius: 10px; background: rgba(255,255,255,0.05);">
<div style="text-align:center; color: #EB811B; font-weight:bold; margin-bottom:10px;">
1. Resolution Error (Bias)
</div>
  
$$A[g] = \int_{0}^\infty d\omega \, \left[ \Delta(\omega) - \delta_\sigma(\omega) \right]^2 e^{2\omega}$$
  
* Penalizes deviations from the **target** $\delta_\sigma$.
* Enforces the correct "smearing shape."
</div>

:::

:::

::: column 
::: {class="fragment"}
<div style="border: 1px solid #444; padding: 15px; border-radius: 10px; background: rgba(255,255,255,0.05);">
<div style="text-align:center; color: #EB811B; font-weight:bold; margin-bottom:10px;">
2. Statistical Error (Variance)
</div>

$$B[g] = \mathbf{g}^T \cdot \mathbf{Cov} \cdot \mathbf{g}$$
  
* Penalizes the **variance** of the estimator due to data noise.
* Reduces explosion of coefficients $g_\tau$.

</div>
:::

:::

:::

<div class="fragment" style="margin-top: 30px; text-align: center;">
  The parameter $\lambda \in [0, 1)$ controls the trade-off. <br>
  <span style="font-size: 0.8em; color: gray;">(Unlike standard Backus-Gilbert, we fix $\sigma$ as an input and scan $\lambda$ for stability.)</span>
</div>

---

Increasing λ damps high‑variance directions; gτ magnitudes collapse.
Color encodes λ; smooth decay shows progressive regularization.

-->

<div style="margin-top:-30px;">

  * **Small $\lambda$ → unstable:**<br> 
      <em style="color:gray;font-weight:400;">Coefficients explode to minimize bias ↔$A$.</em>
  * **Large $\lambda$ → stable:**<br>

  * **Small $\lambda$:** <br>
  <em style="color:gray ;font-weight:400;">Statistical error explodes (noise amplification).</em>
  * **Large $\lambda$:** <br>
  <em style="color:gray ; font-weight:400;">Systematic error dominates (poor resolution).</em>

[**The Sweet Spot:**]{style="color: #EB811B ;"}<br> 
We pick the result on the **plateau** where the value stabilizes <br>before the noise takes over.
:::

## The HLT Algorithm: A Recipe

<div class = "fragment" style="background: rgba(255,255,255,0.05); padding: 20px; border-radius: 15px; border-left: 5px solid #EB811B; margin-top:-5px;">
  **Input:** Euclidean Correlator $G_E(\tau)$ with covariance matrix.
</div>

<div style="margin-left: 20px; margin-top: 20px; font-size: 0.9em;">
  <ol>
    <li class="fragment">**Choose a Target Resolution $\sigma$:** <br> Fix the physical width of the desired smearing $\delta_\sigma(\omega)$:
    

  $$\small \left(\frac{2}{\sigma \pi}\right) \frac{\omega}{\sinh(\omega/\sigma)} \xrightarrow{\sigma \to 0} \delta(\omega) $$
    <li class="fragment">**Scan the Regularization $\lambda$:** <br> Minimize $W_\lambda[g]$ for $\lambda \in [0, 1)$: $$ W_\lambda[g] = (1-\lambda) {A[g]} + \lambda B[g]$$</li>
  </li>
    

    <li class="fragment">**Identify the Stability Plateau:** <br> Plot $\Gamma_\lambda$ vs.  $d=\sqrt{A[g({\color{#EB811B}\lambda})]/A[0]}$ and find the region where systematics and statistics equilibrate.</li>
    <li class="fragment">**Repeat for multiple $\sigma$:** <br>Eventually extrapolate $\sigma \to 0$ </li>
  </ol>
</div>

## New Frontier: Finite Momentum $\Gamma(p)$

<div style="margin-bottom: 20px; text-align:center;">
  We extend the calculation to **non-zero** spatial momentum $\vec{p}$.
</div>

::: columns
::: {.column width="40%" class="fragment"}
  <div style="background: rgba(255,255,255,0.05); padding: 15px; border-radius: 10px; border: 1px solid #444; text-align:center;">
  <strong style="color:#1f77b4">The Observable</strong>
  
  Spatial Fourier Transform:
  $$ Q_L^{\vec{p}}(n_t) = \sum_{\vec{n}} e^{i\vec{p}\cdot\vec{n}} q_L(n_t, \vec{n}) $$
  
  We compute the correlator:
  $$ G^{\vec{p}}(\tau) = \langle Q_L^{\vec{p}}(\tau) Q_L^{-\vec{p}}(0) \rangle $$
  </div>
:::

::: {.column width="60%"}
  <div class="fragment" style="font-size: 1em; margin-top: 10px; padding-left: 15px;">

<div style="margin-top:-10px;"></div>  

  **Why?**
<div style="margin-top:-5px;"></div>

  * Essential for Axion thermal production rates.
  * Probes the spatial structure of topological fluctuations.
  
<div style="margin-top:10px;"></div>  
  **Methodology:**
<div style="margin-top:-5px;"></div>

* Pure SU(3) Gauge Theory
* $T \simeq 1.24 \, T_c$
* $AR=4$ with $N_t \in [12,14,16]$
* **Rigorous Double Extrapolation.**
</div>

:::
:::

## Conclusions 

<div style="font-size: 1em; margin-top: 20px;"></div>

<div class="fragment">

1. **The Inverse Problem:**
    * Spectral reconstruction is ill-posed, but the **HLT (Backus-Gilbert)** strategy allows for a controlled determination of smeared spectral densities via stability analysis.
</div>

<div class="fragment">

2. **Static Sphaleron Rate:**
    * We performed a non-perturbative determination in **Full QCD** $N_f = 2+1$ varying the temperature in the range $T \in [200, 600]$ MeV.
    * The results are consistent with a scaling law $\Gamma_{\text{sphal}} \sim T^2$.
</div>

<div class="fragment">

3. **Finite Momentum (Novel Result):**
    * First systematic study of the momentum dependence in the pure gauge sector.
    * **Unexpected Behavior:** While correlators are suppressed, the physical rate $\Gamma (p)$ **increases** from the static limit before reaching a plateau.
    * This provides a non-trivial input for Axion Boltzmann equations.

</div>
